poem:
**Eighty Years On**

Across this isle of rain and rose,  
we gather, offering cod and flame,  
in echoes of a distant prose—  
this day of pride and name.  
  
Yet some voices, hushed or bold,  
find not a hymn in ancient fire,  
nor taste in traditions old,  
whisper past the rising pyre.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Fish and chips for VE Day? Battle begins over how UK marks 80th anniversary People will be asked to eat fish and chips and sing I Vow To Thee My Country around a chain of beacons to mark the 80th anniversary next year of the end of the second world war. But the plans for 8 May, which are likely to involve the royal family and local councils, have failed to win the support of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
